Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Breakthrough: From Whole-Hand Tactile Imaging to Interactive Simulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to enable cyber-physical systems that can be worn on the body in order to one day allow their users to touch, feel, and manipulate computationally simulated three-dimensional objects or digital data in physically realistic ways, using the whole hand. It will do this by precisely measuring touch and movement-induced displacements of the skin in the hand, and by reproducing these signals interactively, via new technologies to be developed in the project. The resulting systems will offer the potential to impact a wide range of human activities that depend on touch and interaction with the hands. The project seeks to enable new applications for wearable cyber physical interfaces that may have broad applications in health care, manufacturing, consumer electronics, and entertainment. Although human interactive technologies have advanced greatly, current systems employ only a fraction of the sensorimotor capabilities of their users, greatly limiting applications and usability. The development of whole-hand haptic interfaces that allow their wearers to feel and manipulate digital content has been a longstanding goal of engineering research, but has remained far from reality. The reason can be traced to the difficulty of reproducing or even characterizing the complex, action-dependent stimuli that give rise to touch sensations during everyday activities.

This project will pioneer new methods for imaging complex haptic stimuli, consisting of movement dependent skin strain and contact-induced surface waves propagating in skin, and for modeling the dependence of these signals on hand kinematics during grasping. It will use the resulting fundamental advances to catalyze the development of novel wearable CPS, in the form of whole-hand haptic interfaces. The latter will employ surface wave and skin strain feedback to supply haptic feedback to the hand during interaction with real and computational objects, enabling a range of new applications in VR. The project will be executed through research in three main research areas. In the first, it will utilize novel contact and non-contact techniques based on data acquired through on-body sensor arrays to measure whole-hand mechanical stimuli and grasping kinematics at high spatial and temporal resolution. In a second research area, it will undertake data-driven systems modeling and analysis of statistical contingencies between the kinematic and cutaneous sensed during everyday activities. In a third research area, it will engineer and perceptually evaluate novel cyber physical systems consisting of haptic interfaces for whole hand interaction.

In order to further advance the applications of these systems in medicine, through a collaboration with the Drexel College of Medicine, the project will develop new methods for assessing clinical skills of palpation during medical examination, with the aim of improving the efficacy of what is often the first, most common, and best opportunity for diagnosis, using physician's own sense of touch.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was directed at creating new methods for providing haptic (touch) feedback for human interactive cyber-physical systems. The overarching goals of this project were: To create new technologies, including hardware and software methods for electronically imaging complex, tactile signals that are felt by the whole hand; To use these methods to characterize what is felt by the hand during natural touch interactions; and To design new methods for providing haptic (touch) feedback.

In a first area of research, the project developed new methods for imaging the motion of the skin throughout the hand during the tactile object exploration and during object grasping and manipulation with the hand. We achieved this by developing new sensing devices, techniques, and algorithms.  The sensing devices included hand wearable sensor arrays for capturing small vibrations of the skin, by means of arrays of dozens of miniature skin-interfaced vibration-sensitive accelerometers.  These sensor arrays, along with software methods developed in the project, made it possible, for the first time, to characterize whole-hand vibration signatures of natural touch interactions.  We also newly designed and fabricated skin-like electronic sensors for capturing the distributed pressure between the skin and touched objects. The results demonstrated how such whole-hand tactile signals provide sufficient information to accurately computationally classify tactile events, including the object being touched, the properties of those objects, and attributes of palpated soft tissues, such as the presence of subcutaneous tumors. This research also demonstrated how tactile signals distributed throughout the skin of the hand encode the locations of contact with objects that were contacted by remote areas of skin, such as the fingertips. Using these new data and instruments, we also identified parsimonious representations of natural tactile signals in the skin of the human hand. We showed that these low dimensional tactile signal representations were also sufficient to accurately classify natural touch interactions. 

In a second area of research, to take advantage of these new instruments, data, and findings, we developed new wearable electronic devices and methods for providing haptic (touch) feedback.  Informed by the distribution of tactile signals that we captured in the skin using the sensing techniques created in the project, we developed electronic devices for providing tactile feedback.  This yielded miniature soft electromagnetic actuators, which we newly designed and fabricated during the project.  We created these devices using new soft lithography techniques, building on recent advances in composite materials for soft electronics, including highly stretchable electronic wires created in our work. 

This project yielded several new technologies for haptic (touch) sensing and actuation.  These technologies will enable new cyber physical systems for electronically sensing tactile interactions with unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution, and for providing haptic feedback in emerging applications in industry, virtual reality, and entertainment. Their broader impacts include new approaches for the electronic sensing of disease-related differences in body tissues during medical examinations by palpation, and new scientific knowledge that may inform understanding and assessment of diseases affecting the sense of touch.
